trial_identification.studytitle: The effect of spinal manipulation on respiratory function - a pilot study
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The effect of combining spinal manipulation with exercise on the respiratory function of normal individuals

conditions.healthcondition: Change in respiratory function of normal individuals

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Normal development and function of the respiratory system

interventions.interventions: This trial measures the effect of administering spinal manipulation with and without exercise on the respiratory function of normal individuals. Participants with lung volume measurements at the lower end of the normal range are allocated to 4 experimental groups. Group 1 receives exercise only; Group 2 receives spinal manipulation only; Group 3 receives spinal manipulation & exercise; Group 4 receives no intervention (Control). Each participant receives 6 intervention sessions over a 4 week period.

eligibility.exclusivecriteria: A history of respiratory diseaseThe existance of contra-indications to spinal manipulationNon-ambulatory status.

trial_design.concealment: Allocation to intervention groups was concealed by using sealed opaque envelopes.
trial_design.sequence: Group allocation was done by simple randomisation using dice-rolling.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Respiratory function involves movement of structures related to the Cervical and Thoracic spines. Evidence exists that the application of spinal manipulation to these areas can alter respiratory function. This study tests the effect administering spinal manipulation with exercise has on the respiratory function of normal individuals. The aim is to develop a pulmonary rehabilitation protocol that includes spinal manipulation for use in the management of chronic respiratory disease.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Macquarie University Ethics Review Committee (Human Research)
